results.title: Blokes and sheds
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt
results.brief_description:
The backyard shed is an Australian icon. It may appear, to the unenlightened, to be a tacked-together corrugated iron structure full of junk, nails and spiders. In truth, it has become a peculiarly Australian horde of stories and myths about isolation, masculinity, identity, capability, self esteem, tradition and even passionate obsession. It is history on a very human scale, a one-person size record of a life. There is a mystery to a shed, with dark corners; yet grace, too in odd and unexpected ways. By talking to the owners and occupiers of twelve vastly diverse sheds all over South Australia, ‘Blokes and Sheds’ casts a gentle enquiring light into those cobwebbed nooks and crannies to tease out many paradoxes and passions. Each shed is the setting for its owner to open their hearts and share their stories in these twelve, two-minute documentaries.
Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Mark Thomson, Sarah Wishart and Robi Watt

results.title: Richmond 150 years on
results.brief_description: Inner city Richmond (Victoria) celebrates its 150th birthday. Local residents, shop-keepers, community leaders including Ian “Molly” Meldrum and Peter Norden have their say about their beloved Richmond. Whether born there or a recent newcomer, Richmond it seems, is a place of community, fierce loyalty and respect for your neighbour. Includes some wonderful images of past and present including the MCG, Punt Road, Bridge Road, Swan Street, remains of old factories such as Rosella and archival stills of local street scenes. Narrated by Rob Clancy.

results.title: Common ground: Youth Summit 2006
results.brief_description:
‘Youth summit 2006’ is an inspirational collection of works from young people who, through their association with the Western Chances program, have been given the opportunity to tell their stories and build their own bridge to the future. Common Ground is part of the First Person: International Digital Storytelling Conference.
Western Chances was established to ensure that financial hardship does not prevent a young person in Melbourne’s West from achieving their maximum potential in life.

results.title: Selected works from "Bute utes: the movie"
results.brief_description:
A selection of 9 narrative works from across regional Victoria by various storytellers.
Produced by Regional Arts Victoria, ACE Connections, East Gippsland Aboriginal Arts Corporation, Robinvale Cultural Festival and Network House, The South-West Institute of TAFE and the Tarerer Gunditj Association and supported by The Regional Arts Fund, The Myer Foundation and VicHealth.

results.title: Backthenrightnowlateron
results.creator_credit: Luke Monsour, David Megarrity and Queensland Performing Arts Centre
results.brief_description:
Mixing interviews, images and tiny fictions, “Backthenrightnowlateron” is a funny and moving collection of children’s thoughts on their past, present and future.
The work is divided into three segments - Backthen, Rightnow, Lateron. Each segment features children from Class 2J, Yeronga State School, with their favourite toy sharing their thoughts with interviewer Georgia Seffrin, and a mini-film starring one of the toys - Chicky goes to nana’s house, Red Ted goes to England, Minotaur goes to war. Provides a wonderful and amusing insight into young children’s minds.
Developed from an original concept and commission by QPAC’s “Out of the Box” Festival of Early Childhood for the OOTB Symposium, September 2003.

results.title: Stadium
results.brief_description:
Short experimental film capturing the atmosphere of Melbourne’s iconic MCG stadium at night whilst hosting a soccer match during the 2000 Sydney Olympics.
No commentary, using sound effects only.

results.title: Rowing on the Yarra
results.brief_description: A beautifully photographed portrait of Melbourne’s busy Yarra River during the rowing season with the Hoddle Bridge and passing automobile traffic framing the background using timelapse cinematography. A nostalgic feel to the film is conveyed through the use of tinted monochrome colouring and a music soundtrack.
